comments.commentBody: I'm trying to use a little imagination to see what BARE X AM means.
BAR EXAM is a wonderful fill.  With a little imagination this can quickly become BARE X AM.

Or we could take the interpretation that we should get dogs, not guns.

No hidey hole for Feinberg this time. I like the way this column calls him out.
I agree, very scary, unfortunately very predictable.
But there are sufficient whackos to get these whackos elected. You have my commisserations for having to live in a state with so many whackos. Any ideas on what can be done to change this?
If Oklahoma makes this legislation law, Obama should stop all federal funding for education from the state.

Oklahoma couldn't wait. The legislature was given a bill today that would require all adult staff at public schools to carry guns, from the principal to the janitor. Since mental health is the topic of discussion all over America, the first question should be, "What the devil is wrong with the politicians in Oklahoma and the people who elect them?" I'm speaking as a person who lives here, but didn't elect any of the whackos we have in the legislature.
Nevermind on the second Sunday blogs--Noon Saturday.

An easy SATXWP with all the fifteens and relative lack of Naticks.

I did the diagramless today, but I can never remember when those special blogs come out. It's confusing since there is a delay we don't get with the daily puzzles. The diagramless is usually easier for me than the Saturday daily. Not so today. I had to get deep into the SW before I could get a toehold in the NE.

Bibi Netanyahu's brother, Jonathan, was part of an elite unit of the Israel Defense Forces. He died on a mission to rescue passengers whose flight was highjacked and taken to Uganda. His unit had trained specifically for the rescue mission.

The risks are not lessened by the presence of more people with guns, not even highly trained ones.

20/20 did a segment on what happens when there are lots of guns in an attack. It's worth the few minutes. http://www.upworthy.com/the-nra-thinks-more-guns-are-the-answer-bless-th...
I thought it was a standard symptom of people with certain (narcissistic?) traits -- trying to project onto another one's own flaws.

The N.R.A. has decided that from now on, whenever there is another school mass shooting, the N.R.A. will blame all who opposed their guns everywhere solution. This pattern is disturbingly similar to the Republicans working so hard to crash the economy so they can blame Obama for the crashed economy because he did not adopt their solutions.

America may be in for a very ugly time if all the rabid ferrets, vampires, and zombies existing in the land continue their attack on the fabric of civilized society.
I thought it was a standard symptom of people with certain (narcissistic?) traits -- trying to project onto another one's own flaws.

The N.R.A. has decided that from now on, whenever there is another school mass shooting, the N.R.A. will blame all who opposed their guns everywhere solution. This pattern is disturbingly similar to the Republicans working so hard to crash the economy so they can blame Obama for the crashed economy because he did not adopt their solutions.

America may be in for a very ugly time if all the rabid ferrets, vampires, and zombies existing in the land continue their attack on the fabric of civilized society.

Deadline – For ICE RUN, imagine living on the shore of a large lake, where in the winter the ice freezes solid enough that you can drive vehicles on it to get to your favorite ice-fishing spot. In the spring, when the ice breaks up and flows out, you may call this the ice run. Anne LaBastille, in “Woodswoman”, her account of life in the Adirondack wilderness, simply calls it “the breakup”.
I didn't realize people got out of jail in China.
Now that we're all still here, the Chinese might consider letting the apocalypse horsemen out of jail.

Correction -- this should have read: the vast majority of gun deaths are *NOT* due to a mentally-ill shooter.

My apologies!
That bill needs to be shot down.  No pun intended.
Oklahomans should vote out of office the sponsors of that ludicrous bill.   They should fire them now, if possible.
i would support that, but only for the janitors.
The Oklahoma legislature has a bill before it that would require all teachers, principals, office staff and janitors at schools to be armed with guns.

The conservative movement has become adept at placing the blame on the victim. This is a classic case of reversing cause and effect.

One can understand gun collecting, they are works of art in many cases. You do not see armed robberies or random murders by people with a Walker Colt, or Sharps Repeating Rifle.

There are some modern guns that true collectors want, such as a Thompson Sub-machine gun, or Tommy gun. and you can get a permit to have one, but there are restrictions. On the other hand, assault rifles or facsimiles. have no use other than to increase ones firepower.. They are not accurate enough for larger game, they are not good for competition, their purpose is to kill as may people as possible in the shortest amount of time.

What we saw with La Pierre today was a perverted view of public responsibility.
Here is a man that is an expert at avoiding responsibility for these acts of evil, and he does so not as I see it to protect a right to bear arms, but to profit from leading an organization that has glorified the means to destroy innocent lives for the profits of an industry of death.

P.S. Guns in people's homes for "protection" are far more likely to be used for suicide, to kill one's spouse, or to accidentally kill a child playing with it than to be used against an intruder; and on the exceedingly remote occasion when it is pulled on an intruder, the most likely outcome is that it will be taken away and used to kill the gun's owner.

Ah, the sacred right to keep automatic weapons in the home. If Adam Lanza's mother wasn't so enthralled with her 2nd amendment rights and having her own personal armory, Sandy Hook Elementary School would probably be just another small & nice school in Connecticut that the rest of the world never heard of, and not the scene of a massacre of 1st graders and school staff.

Agree 100% with your p.s., as we shouldn't be appalled only at mass killings such as last week's. A child killed while 'playing' with a gun found in their home is every bit as tragic.

Also, it often happens that the gun kept in your home is stolen during a break-in, and used in still another crime.

In San Francisco in the neighborhood I lived in a few madman "patriots" paranoid about "one world government," the UN, "tyranny," and "peril" owned guns, undoubtedly assault weapons among them.

These people are crazy.

The people who own assault weapons to defend America against tin-foil-hat delusions are insane.

These are the people who buy assault weapons.

Hunters and homeowners afraid of home invasion don't.

Banning assault weapons and high-capacity clips are opposed by gun-nut "patriots" who are crazy.

Everyone else supports it.

This newspaper published an interactive map of congressional districts disclosing the NRA ranking and NRA campaign contributions each Representative and Senator received. The map can be found here http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2012/12/19/us/politics/nra.html

I've been gerrymandered from a district represented by a congressman with an NRA ranking of F to a district represented by a congressman with a ranking of A+. I plan to make all my senators and representative aware of my support for gun control. I would suggest that everyone else do the same.

My congressman received $4500 from the NRA - I'm pretty sure I can find enough people in this district to make double that in campaign contributions to an opponent favoring gun control.

Regardig the senate: I agree with Phil that it has become more and more undemocratic, given the huge differences in population between the states. Just to illustrate: 9 states contain mor than 50 % of the population, but they have 18 senators, i.e. 18 % of the senate. And, mind you, these are the states wit the most important economic, financial, educational and cultural centres. California's popualtion is the same as the 22 (!) least populous states together. These 22 states have 44 senators, whereas California has just 2. Any reason why one vote for the senate in Wyoming is equal to 67 votes in California?
And the biggest flaw in the constitution is the process to change/amend it. That has been made far too difficult. Antonin Scalia once calculated that an amendement to the constitution can be stopped by as little as 2 % of the electorate.

To Phil Dauber Alameda, California:

While I can sympathize with your argument, since I too, live in a heavily populated state, I do not think the Senate’s structure is purely due to “fear of excessive democracy”.

Rather, since the founders began with 13 states ranging in size from small states like Rhode Island to large ones such as New York, without the Senate, the country would be ruled by the large states such as New York, California and Texas.

As my fellow New Yorker, Danny Mccay, points out, gerrymandering is a problem: The Dems got more votes for the House in 2012, but the GOP won more seats. We need better reapportionment after the 2020 census.

Meanwhile, there are no easy answers. Write, email your Congressperson, Senator and President. 180,000 Americans signed the Petition to the President demanding gun control (I did too).

The problem lies in gerrymandering. These congressman are from districts that are overwhelmingly Caucasian, districts that do believe in god and guns, and are so entrenched that the interests of the country mean little. They won't bite the hand that feeds them. Unfortunately, that hand belongs to someone who's view of reality must be questioned. These are the same people who made it clear they wanted the government to keep its hands off of Medicare...

How many armed guards would there have to be in a school to prevent what happened in Newtown?  One in every classroom -- at least.  How many armed guards would that be in total?  Half a million -- at least?  Well at least it would lower the unemployment rate.
These bullets are called "cop killing" bullets for a reason.

Excellent summation of La Pierre's insane idea.

Does the NRA want to post armed guards at every movie theater, every shopping mall, and every work place too? Our children, mothers, sisters, fathers and brothers have died in those places too. I was reading that a $31k annual tax on every gun in the nation would pay for the $8-billion-dollar stupid idea from La Pierre. If you want to arm those places too, how about if we tax the owners of assault weapons to put gun-toting guards on every street corner, at every amusement park, in every single place where someone might shoot--oh, wait, that could be anywhere.

Body-armor piercing bullets, 30-round clips: these are not civilian toys. Ban them. Let people keep their civilian guns. Get rid of the rest.

I was once in an automobile going 50 mph on a two lane black top when both the brakes and steering failed. There were no seat belts in that old 1934 Chevy. There was slow moving traffic ahead. My dad was at the wheel. He blow the horn, put the car in 1st gear and allowed the tires to come into contact with a high curb on the right. I was old enough to know what a car wreck would mean and it was pure luck that there was a high curb and the car drifted to the right instead of into incoming traffic. The car was out of control and I awaited my fate. No one hurt but the car was junked.

We now have crazies with guns killing people by the dozens, guns a blazing, mindless of the damage they were doing or intending to inflict that damage because the inner demons were telling them what to do. Republicans and guns go together. We are coming out of a great recession and people are being crushed by economic inequality and government is paralyzed by fanatics, wackaloons, corrupt politicians and outright fascists. We are to be held hostage with our economies national and personal at stake. We are in the midst of a coup d’etat. The Republicans lost the election and now demand, of promise of anarchy, that we proceed as though Romney won the election. Every legal channel is blocked. Shall we then have an all powerful Executive branch as we would have had Romney won? The GOP, now a leaderless mob to the U.S.: You elected Obama now you get Romney or a depression. Sane people take cover.
When they say it's not about the money, it's about the money! -  H. L. Mencken

Janice,

That's a horrible story about the 2-yer old, but it's not about the gun, really. It's about the supremely irresponsible and stupid gun owner - someone who would leave a loaded handgun under a couch!

Had the gun been some caustic chemical, lighter, a poisonous snake, etc., the situation would still have been tragic. Yes, a gun is a dangerous object, as are the other ones I mentioned. The problem is with the owner who doesn't have the brains to responsibly manage the gun/chemical/lighter/snake.

Hating the gun does nothing to address the owner, who is the real problem. I have owned guns for many years, with my own children in the house, and this situation could never have happened to us, as I am smart enough to know how to responsibly store weapons so there is no danger of them inadvertently being used to hurt anyone.

On the other side of the coin, the NRA is being as reckless with its stance as any organization in recent memory. Guns, like caustic chemicals and poisonous snakes, have their proper place in society (I would argue), but only for those who are responsible enough to own them. And since the right to gun ownership is not absolute, there ought to be reasonable limits placed on them.

They won't care. To them, an accidental shooting victim, no matter how young, is simply collateral damage, a tragic price we have to pay to keep the country free by ensuring that the country is awash in weapons that they fantasize will allow them to rise up against their own government if and when they get angry enough. If kids die, well, it's a tragedy, but taking the guns away would be an even greater tragedy.

These are not rational people; these are zealots, fanatics, and true believers who live inside a separate universe where the only information they get is from their fellow zealots. Go to any of the RW sites and look at the commentary there (and really, seriously, go and have a look for yourself. not kidding. it's scary.) regarding the shootings and the reactions to it. To them, the problem is never too many guns, it's always not enough guns. The only way to protect us all from bad guys with guns is to fill the streets with good guys with guns. Ine very instance, they KNOW that if THEY had been there, things would have turned out differently because THEY would have drawn their guns and leaped into action, taking down the bad guy with one well aimed shot, just like in the movies.

For the gun fanatic, shooting deaths are an abstraction - either poor victims who should have been protected by an armed good guy, or a bad guy killed by a good guy. Their guns are their reality. And their reality will always protect them from the abstractions of everyone else's reality.

When I was a young nurse in the ER, decades ago, I helped to take care of a 2 year old shot by her young 5 year old brother who found a loaded gun under the couch and shot her through the neck. I can still picture the whole scene to this day. She died. It was awful. I have hated guns since that day. There are few good outcomes when guns and people collide. Actually I have witnessed none.

As for the NRA who want to place guns in everyone's hands I say to them that they should all be forced to witness and help victims of gun violence. They need to see the outcomes of the policies they implore our politicians to uphold. And why are our politicians pándering to them? I just simply do not get why the vocal minority wins all the time.

Kudos, Gail and the saner commenters.
May I suggest we take "baby steps", as Richard Dreyfuss's psychiatrist character tells Bill Murray in "What About Bob?", a drill, bright movie?
First, we must control import, then production, and finally resale of semi-automatic weapons. More regs can follow later.
We must start a simple buyback of all such idioptic toys already owned. With a bonus that shrinks every 60 days. A tax credit or cash. More guns-bubacks to follow.
we must ask that Scalia nd Thomas recuse themselves from cases involving conservative causes. They are not judges, they are, on these matters, advocates. Later we can urge Liberal replacements.

we should remove charitable and non-profit status from gun-lobbying groups.
later we can overturn Citizens United.

We need a Million Mom March on Washington every spring until concealed guns in federally-subsidized courthouses, airports, and educational institutions are removed -- or the federal support will be.

Later... ah, we can breathe easily and talk about increased mental heath care and support.

Let us plan that march and support a decade of reversing gun-availability and -reliance. Let us start now by naming Dec. 16th "Gun Control day".

You knocked it out of the ballpark with that thought. Bear in mind they say an armed society will lead to a more polite one.  My question is who defines " polite" ? As a loud liberal lawyer from NY I wonder how many times I would have been shot to date as a result of my failure to be polite  in the minds of those bearing assault weapons and or concealed weapons .

Isn't that chilling? You are right--that is what they are advocating. Every church pew, movie seat, teacher's desk, grocery store, and doctor's waiting room full of armed "good" people. Doesn't that sound like some futuristic movie that should be completely fictional?

Yep. I think I'll keep advocating with you, that this has to stop now. There have to be more of us than there are of them.

I went Christmas shopping tonight at a crowded mall. I imagined everyone armed with a gun. Everyone. That's what the NRA is really advocating. Guns in schools, in churches, in hospitals, everywhere because "good" people, properly armed, will keep us safe according to Mr. LaPierre.

People who advocate such lunacy in the name of public safety damage the opportunity to live in a civil society. This has to stop now.
It all sounded very reasonable, until the part about committing those who publicly disagree with you to an insane asylum.
Plus the NRA must buy free kevlar vests for all the school children. Noisy airports pay for three-fold windows in the neighbourhood, no?

Have you forgotten Columbine? VA Tech? Fort Hood?  All had "armed guards"  A gun man maybe crazy but not stupid since the first person they take out is the "armed guards"   Honestly sticker gun laws, taxes on guns and ammunition and required liability insurance of gun owners will do more good coupled with increased  funding of mental health paid for by the taxing of the guns and ammunition.

I'm okay with the idea of installing armed guards at school buildings provided that they're paid for by taxes levied on the purchase of guns and ammunition.  Which wouldn't obviate the need to outlaw assault weapons, semi automatics and the clips that "feed" them.  And to enforce background checks at gun shows.  And to get rid of all lawmakers who accept campaign money from the NRA.  And to commit Wayne LaPierre to an insane asylum.

CL
Vengeance covering 4 years is a stretch whereas in the same season and against the same personnel is more attainable.
If you don't see my point then you are myopic.
Certainly no need to be a Belichick...who needs Super Bowl Rings? Way over rated.

While this commentary has many good points, the "him or me" conclusion is frankly way off the mark.

When it comes to achieving success, the issue is first, last, and always "are you effective?" Being effective means placing the focus on what needs to be done in order to achieve the desired end result. What being effective does not necessarily mean is being cold, calculating, and adversarial with those you are responsible for leading. In Rex's case, his inability to step away from himself (and those he coaches and manages) and objectively see if what he is doing is working. If it isn't, then he is not being effective. If it is, then he is being effective.

The next step in this process is to evaluate - objectively and dispassionately (and most definitely not with tears in your eyes because you are out of the playoffs) - why things are as they are. If ineffective (as in losing), then answers must be found to problems that exist. However, if effective (as in winning), then an equally vigorous effort must be undertaken to determine why things are going well so that an understanding of where, how, what, who, and why the success has come about. Talent? Good decision-making? Luck?

One can most definitely be humane, considerate, respectful, and caring and still be effective. In other words, there's no need to be heartless, ruthless, etc. to be successful. No need to be "him or me". No need to be a Belichick. Just a commitment to success, which is a commitment to being effective.
He cannot put the talent on the field if it doesn't exist in the locker room.  Ryan is not responsible for personnel

But, eddhead, isn't Ryan getting input on the personnel.
For instance, my problem with the piece is the same as all the accolades Ryan ever gets related to his AFC finals appearances -- they were achieved with personnel acquired during the "Mangini Era" which was capsized by Favre, which was a Woody move.
Always comes back to upper management. And Ryan was, again, a Woody move.

Without realizing it, Trevor revealed Ryan's real problem when he said Ryan would be among the best if all teams had the same talent level. That's unrealistic.

A coach's first responsibility is the ability to judge talent and then have what it takes to put that talent on the field.

No one does it any better than Belichick and no ex-Patriot has ever criticized him because he knows what he is doing and he is honest with them. No BS.
